text: The act of expressing, conveying, or representing in words, art, music, or movement; a manifestation:  an expression of rural values.
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition

text: Something that expresses or communicates:  Let this plaque serve as an expression of our esteem.
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition

text: Mathematics   A symbol or combination of symbols that represents a quantity or a relationship between quantities.
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition

text: The manner in which one expresses oneself, especially in speaking, depicting, or performing.
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition

text: A particular word or phrase: "an old Yankee expression . . . 'Stand up and be counted'”  ( Charles Kuralt).
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition

text: The outward manifestation of a mood or a disposition:  My tears are an expression of my grief.
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition

text: A facial aspect or a look that conveys a special feeling:  an expression of scorn.
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition

text: The act of pressing or squeezing out.
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition

text: Genetics   The act or process of expressing a gene.
attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 4th Edition
